Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: You are scheduled to be a guest on a live radio show to discuss your cause, and the segment starts in five minutes.
Story: I glance at my phone, heart pounding. My boyfriend is waiting at the café down the street, texting me sweet reminders about our long-overdue date night. We both finally have free evenings, and he’s been looking forward to this—just us, no distractions. But as I slip on my coat, my phone buzzes again. It’s a reminder from the radio station: I’m scheduled to go live in five minutes to talk about our campaign, a rare chance to reach thousands and maybe make a real difference. My mind races. He expects me to be present, to laugh and share stories over coffee, to show him he matters. But my fellow activists are counting on me to speak up, to educate, to be the voice for our cause. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, my stomach twisting as I stand in the hallway, torn between love and responsibility, knowing I can’t be in two places at once.
